ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was exposed to a wide range of perspectives regarding post-graduate opportunities. Each guest lecturer gave insights and advice on navigating a career in their particular field. We also had hands-on experience identifying what our personal strengths and interests were as well as propose a specific aims topic and present it at the end of the semester.
I learned about the many ways my biomedical engineering major can be used in my future career path!
Insights into what kind of career and future I want to have! Honestly more valuable than learning about engineering material.
Really knowledgable speakers and great insights into the different fields we can go into after getting a biomedical engineering degree.
Learning from professionals in the realm of biomedical engineering was an absolute treat.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths are that we were exposed to a wide range of perspectives regarding post-graduate opportunities.

I think a big strength of this course is how light the workload is: I could just come to class and listen and take away from the session what I thought was important without having to stress about what was due and when and how I was going to get it all in.  Another strength is that the speakers were from such a wide variety of backgrounds I did really feel like we got a taste of everything.

Strengths: Dr. Saxena is a gem, she's so sweet and it's clear that she really cared about how the course was presented and how we interacted with it.
Weaknesses: This is more an inherent feature of guest speakers, but it was hard to stay tuned in and engaged for lectures week after week.

Strengths: it was clear that the syllabus was very thoughtfully planned -- there was a really comprehensive variety of guest speakers who were a great launching pad for seniors considering different career paths that involve a BME degree
Weaknesses: not enough engagement with the professor or my classmates; would have been nice if the final project was developed more during class (rather than on our own time)

Shreya did an amazing job of selecting speakers for this class, and I wish that BENG 280 could be similar to this. I wish I knew about these different options as a sophomore when I just started doing BME so that I could better shape my experience into striving for one of these sects.
We had a lot of consulting people come in, which was slightly unrelated to the major. Having people from an even broader range of professions would be great, although what we did have was lovely.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Would recommend for biomedical engineering seniors!

This is required for BME majors so obviously a recommendation is not really important, however I do really think it's a great addition to the BME coursework.  I almost wish it was when we were juniors and not seniors but I think junior year is so full of the 350 level classes that it'd be too tight to fit it in for a lot of people.
Yes! Requirement for BME majors, honestly wish that the sophomore seminar was more like this.
100%. you get to meet a bunch of CEOs, executives, doctors, scientists. It's awesome. take it even if you aren't BME major. easy A as well.
Yes, absolutely. It's required for seniors in the major but I think anyone can learn a lot from it.
